intorduction.p: Factoring can help us analyze a polynomial. In particular, for polynomials in one variable, factoring may help us find the x-intercepts of the graph.

solution.p: First, factor out the common factor, ~4xy. 4x^3y-12x^2y-40xy = 4xy(x^2-3x-10) Now factor the quadratic trinomial. We need two numbers p and q that satisfy ~pq=-10~~~~ \text{and}~~~~ p+q=-3~ By trial and error we find ~p=-5~ and ~q=2~, so x^2-3x-10 = (x-5)(x+2) and thus 4x^3y-12x^2y-40xy = 4xy(x-5)(x+2)
We want to find two factors so that ~8x^2-21x-9 = (ax+b)(cx+d). Now ~(ax+b)(cx+d) = adx^2 +(ad+bc)x + bd~ so ~(ad)(bc)=8(-9)=-72~ and ~ad+bc=-21.~

To simplify the calculations, we let ~p=ad~ and ~q=bc~. We need to find the two numbers p and q that satisfy ~pq=-72~~~~ \text{and}~~~~ p+q=-21~ By trying different factors of -72, we find that ~p=-24~ and ~q=3~.

introduction.p: Here is more practice using formulas to factor the special quadratic and cubic polynomials.

solution.p: From the square terms we see that a=x^2 and b=12. We check that the middle term is -2ab. -2ab=-2(x^2)(12)=-24x^2 The polynomial fits the pattern for (a-b)^2, so x^4-24x^2+144 = (x^2-12)^2

The polynomial is the sum of two cubes, with x=3t and y=2v. We substitute these values into the formula. (x+y)(x^2-xy+y^2) \amp = (3t+2v)((3t)^2-(3t)(2v)+(2v)^2) \amp =(3t+2v)(9t^2-6tv+4v^2) Thus, 27t^3+8v^2= (3t+2v)(9t^2-6tv+4v^2)

subsection.title: 3. Divide polynomials

introduction.p: If a polynomial cannot be factored, we can use a process like long division to write it as a quotient plus a remainder.
